title: Measuring Spoons in Hard-To-Find and Useful Sizes

description.text:
My brother likes to drink tea, but not the kind that comes in teabags. He likes gourmet teas which have to be measured into a tea strainer for each cup, and his favorite tea requires him to measure two teaspoons of tea leaves to make a cup of tea. It turns out that nobody makes a 2 tsp measuring spoon, so he's always forced to measure two scoops instead of having a conveniently-sized measure which corresponds to exactly one cup's worth of tea leaves. This was an obvious application for a 3d printer. I designed a 2 tsp measuring spoon, using a hemisphere for the scoop so I could calculate exactly how big it needed to be. I gave it a large handle which allows it to sit exactly level on the counter, and as a final touch, embossed "2 tsp" on the handle so there's no doubt how much it holds. But why stop there? I occasionally have to measure 4 tsp (or 1 1/3 Tbsp) when I'm cooking, so I designed a 4 tsp measuring spoon. This lets me get in one scoop what used to take four. Then it occurred to me: there are all kinds of useful sizes for measuring spoons which are impossible to find in the store. In particular, even the best gourmet cooking stores never seem to carry measuring spoons in increments based on mathematical and physical constants. Hence, my set of Measuring Spoons in Hard-To-Find and Useful Sizes. The sizes included in this set are: 2 tsp
4 tsp
pi tsp (pi is the ratio of a circle's circumference to its diameter, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pi )
alpha gallons (alpha is the fine structure constant, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fine-structure_constant )
e Tbsp (e is the base of the natural logarithm, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E_(mathematical_constant) )
phi fluid ounces (phi is the golden ratio, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_ratio )

• Print
  • Keep around the kitchen
  • Make puns about baking pi (optional)
    • For those who wonder why these measuring spoons are English rather than metric: If you're going to make an irrational measuring spoon, it only makes sense to use an irrational measuring system, too.

title: FlyBy Community - Multi-Task Racing Drone Tool

description.text:
Thinking on our racing drone community needs I grab one idea here and there and create this nice tool, everybody on the hobby should have one thing like thins on you FPV bag.

Don't overtight you SMA or propeller Hex Flange M5 because a overtight prop or shaft can damage you motor, this is a important thing on the racing drone hobby and this tool give you total confidence and security of your pre-check flight list.

Join to our Facebook Community, (https://www.facebook.com/groups/1757556567891477/)
Help us and help all community with your ideas/knowledge and questions, everybody is welcome, give always all weeks on amazing new FPV product. Come and join us!

Note: This tool take around 5 to 10 minutes printed on standard quality, you don't need fine detail, needs around a meter of filament, you don't need be crazy strong one just need don't do total infill, 30% infill is ok because they need be flexible.

Please: don't take this on the commercial away, print just for you and your friends, thank you for respect and support our community and creators.

Thank you! Show you tool and help us to improve this and another's projects we have on.

Do you like this design and want more great projects? Donate a dollar or two to help order future supplies :-) http://bit.ly/2qQuoQ0

author: francisLM

description.text:
This is a duct for the trigorilla mainboard mounted with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:758141. It is designed to fit both the plus and non plus version, and requires raised feet on the delta to clear. It is designed to cool the steppers with a 40mmx 40mm high static pressure fan. It will clear the stepper motor, and will pull in fresh cooler air away from the heated bed, and push it through the stepper duct, and out a round hole pointed away from the heated bed. I will make an exhaust duct for it soon...but for now it should work great and keep the air mostly off the bed. You can use some kind of wire loom or something to route it away if you want.

There is a file with the whole part for plus printers, and a part cut for smaller printers. Full supports required. Face the fan flange down, and the stepper hole up.

author: JBurdette5

description.text:
Available for download is a model rocket. The parts only consist of the rocket nose cone and rocket base. These two parts should fit nicely with the estes cardboard tube. The cardboard body tube can be purchased at the estes website or amazon. Body tube model that fits is the BT-50 Body Tubes with a 0.95 in. inner diameter. The rocket base will accommodate model engine A8-3. The engine should fit snug (solid press fit) but if not, look closely, and you will notice a hole in the bottom of the rocket base to insert and glue in an engine hook. The base of the nose cone has a feature so you can tie the parachute to it. The nose cone should fit snug, but not overly tight to allow for the deployment of the parachute. The rocket base however, should have very tight press fit. I have tested and launched the rocket so it I know it works well (check out the video).

PLEASE NOTE the .stl files are smaller and need to be scaled 10 times larger to obtain the correct size.

For best results print with supports and a raft. I use very little infill and wall thickness in the nose cone to make it light as can be.
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/RI_CvNCBRwY" ></iframe>
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/RI_CvNCBRwY" ></iframe>
Additional materials: You will need to supply your own parachute, body tube, interior wadding, and launch pad accessories

title: Front spool holder for Prusa i3 MK2

description.text:
20-04-2017
Filament spool holder without axis, on the front side of the printer.
Support de bobine de filament sans axe, positionné à l'avant de l'imprimante.

Filament spool change is very fast and easy.
Ainsi, le changement de bobine est facile et rapide.

For 1 set of supports you need 4 ball bearings 608ZZ and 4 screws CHC M3x16.
Pour un jeu de supports, vous avez besoin de 4 roulements 608ZZ et de 4 vis CHC M3x16.

22-04-2017
I slightly modified the right and left arms by pre-tapping the M3 fixing holes of the diabolo rollers on the arms. I also slightly increased the clipping on the gantry.

J'ai légèrement modifié les bras droit et gauche en pré-taraudant les trous M3 de fixation des galets diabolo sur les bras. J'ai aussi augmenté très légèrement le clipsage des bras sur le portique.

25-04-2017
Ajouté un guide nettoyeur de filament. Optimiation du clipsage sur le portique.

Added a filament cleaner guide. Snap fit optimisation on the frame.

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Nozzle 0,4mm

20-04-2017
You have to bore the 4 holes with 2,5mm drill before taping M3.
Il faut recalibrer les 4 trous de fixation des galets avec un foret de 2,5 mm avant de les tarauder avec un taraud M3. Tarauder très lentement pour éviter l'échauffement du PLA.

The holes to store the filament need adjustment with 2mm drill.
Les trous de rangement du filament en attente seront réalésés avec un foret de 2 mm.

22-04-2017
Modification of the right and left arms should allow the M3x16 CHC screws to be screwed without any prior tapping.
La modification des bras droit et gauche doit permettre de visser les vis CHC M3x16 sans taraudage préalable.

-Vastly improved Metatarsals
-Corrected Foot alignment
-Talus has been completely revamped from a low polygon retopology from 123D Catch reconstruction of Cadaver Specimen. There are 26 proper bones in the human foot; 28 if you consider the sesamoids of the 1st metatarsal phalangeal joint complex. That's over 25% of your body's total musculo-skeletal anatomy, hitting the ground every time you go for a walk or run! Quite impressive, really. Read More:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foot
http://www.learnbones.com/foot-bones-anatomy This anatomic foot model was designed in Newtek's Lightwave 3D, as part of the podcast @ www.YouTube.com/DrGlassDPM Anatomic study models can be quite expensive, http://search.anatomywarehouse.com/search?keywords=foot&x=0&y=0 so I wanted to share my printable version with the Thingiverse crowd and give a big shout out to Freeside Atlanta's Hackerspace!

Version 2: I've decided not to include individual STL's of each bone. Instead, I've included the Lightwave LWO file, which has every bone (and skin) in low poly. It will be easier this way for me to update the model at a faster rate. Otherwise, I'd be impressed to see some of the techniques towards printing this and having a clean separation from support material. This (and deriviatives thereof) will hopefully rival things like: molded study models http://search.anatomywarehouse.com/search?keywords=foot&x=0&y=0

description.text: Camera mount for an ImmersionRC Alien 5" body (Also bolts directly to the "ButterKwad" kit). Direct bolt to the frame using the stock allen screws, gives the camera a 25° tilt. I designed this to hold both the GoPro Hero/NoPro style camera and the GoPro Session/RunCam 2 or RunCam 3 style camera. There are horizontal and vertical strap slots, either can be used depending on the camera that you have. This has been a very robust camera mount so far. I've had a few good crashes with multiple quads and none of these have broken yet. Took me 4 different designs but I finally got something that works!

30%

Notes:

I've only ever printed this with ABS+ plastic so I'm not sure how other types would hold up. I used a bed temp of 100°C and a nozzle temp of 240°C.

Delamination Issues

I haven't had any delamination issues with this design or the plastic that I've been using, but smearing a thin layer of super glue along the outside would help during hard crashes.

title: Miniature RPi Camera enclosure / case (M2.5 edition)

description.text:
Fits this product sold by Adafruit: https://www.adafruit.com/products/1937

Extrusion width: 0.48mm

Printing notes

This case was designed around a 0.48mm extrusion width. This gives the features on the case a bit of added strength. If the case isn't printing quite right, try adjusting the slicer's extrusion width.

Enclosure Hardware (Bill of Materials)

2x M2.5 x 16mm
2x M2.5 Hex Nuts or 2x M2.5 Nylock Nut

The ones used for testing were sourced from Trimcraft Aviation RC -- these should also be available on Amazon and McMaster-Carr.

Fasteners are ideal to tie everything together, but in a pinch, other stuff works too (i've tried all of these except for filament hot tapping:

  • Zip ties (tightening the tie sets position).
  • Glue (cyanoacrylates/hot glue).
  • Straightened 1.75mm filament (roll it on a heated bed) hot tapped with a soldering iron to fix it onto the ends.
  • Tying somewhat flexible filament together (gets tricky, but it works).

Assembly

  • Print everything individually, including the case covers.

  • Weave the camera cable into the case.

  • Cover everything, adjust positioning with the screws/other hardware.

  • Connect to a Pi.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

0.48mm extrusion width

Nozzle: 0.4 mm
Material: PLA (Ultimachine Red Translucent / Atomic Filament Extreme Impact Gun Metal Gray v2 PLA)
Printer: Prusa i3 MK2

description.text: I purchased the Master Lock Word Lock (model 1534D) to use with my BreakoutEDU box but was not happy that I was limited on what 5 letter words I could spell with the provided letter and number dials, so I made my own! I can print one of these off my Makerbot printer in about 36 minutes with the settings I've included. I've got files for A-Z (the U-Z dial also has !, &, and ? symbols on it) and also a dial with arrows (for directional lock configurations) as well as some basic shapes for primary students.

MakerBot

10%

I use 2 shells, roof and floor thickness of 1.00 mm and have been printing at 218°C with pretty good results.

title: Lulzbot Mini USB Socket & Cord Saver

description.text: This is an accessory for the USB type B socket on a Lulzbot Mini 3D printer. After a lot of connecting and de-connecting cables from mine, the socket's solder points weakened and the port ripped straight out of the Rambo control board, so I designed this insert to prevent that problem (It is possible to replace that USB port, but it sure was a hassle for me). Print with the "pyramid" upside-down, I did mine with a brim to ensure a nice bond to the bed. When installing, just slide the insert into the air gap between the port and the metal enclosure, with the open side facing the right. Enjoy!

description.text:
Based on idea of two piece shift knob of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1488711
Uses 3 M6x20 screws, that cut directly into holes of bottom part.
Bottom screws directly on shifter shaft. Subaru forester with manual transmission uses M12x1.25 thread. Such locking nut can be placed inside the bottom part. (I didn't use one).

I used PLA. But be aware that temperature inside cabin can be well above 50°C, when PLA starts to soften and deform. Therefore, PLA is not the best choice for part, like a shifting knob. Give a shot PETG/ASA, or good ol' ABS.

I found the Cartoon of Leon Theremin in the web (In Pinterest, not a reliable source to credit the author https://de.pinterest.com/pin/331014641335771182/)

I am an Electronic Engineer and have no idea of CAD, so I made the stupid decision of designing the case with EagleCad (File attached). Don't be lazy and learn some CAD so you don't have to deal with the incorrect tool :-)

description.text:
This is a simple model of the newest incarnation of the USS Enterprise (from the end of Star Trek Beyond) designed to be printed for desktop display.

The model is made of six parts and (due to pylon angle) can be printed without support material and without a raft. All parts glue nicely together with gorilla glue.

Feel free to reach out to me with issues in the model!

Notes:
The top of the saucer prints very thin, be careful!
Pardon the incomplete render on the side view, I got impatient.
I have printed mine but have yet to assemble it yet. Stay tuned!

title: Yootech Qi Wireless charger and phone holder for Mountek

description.text:
For years now i've used the Mountek nGroove CD slot phone holder, but now that I've had wireless charging with my Samsung Galaxy 6 edge and then S7 Edge I wanted the same thing but with a wireless charger built in...couldn't find it so i created this add on for the Mountek nGroove CD slot mount and a Yootech round Qi wireless charger.
The only parts you'll need for assembly are a small bolt, washer, and nut, you'll simply take apart the mountek phone holder by unscrewing the screw in the back of it, then put this on on in it's place using a bolt washer and nut. I recommend a locking nut.
This fits my Samsung S7 Edge with a case on it and still has some room to grow, so slightly larger or smaller phone may still fit fine. The USB is a little tight fit but i found that it helps hold the Qi charger in place once pushed into the slot.
Below are links to the Mountek and Yootech that I used:
Mountek nGroove Universal CD Slot Mount for Cell Phones and GPS Devices
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004G1L52Q/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Yootech ~69mm Diameter and 9mm thick
***I found that Amazon may not be carrying this exact one anymore, but I see it on ebay for cheap still if you search for YooTech T200PB. There may be other chargers that will work just have to make sure the dimensions are NO larger than 70mm x 10mm
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00SJ0MWCM/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

When printing use some supports touching build plate, the area where the bolt attaches is open underneath to all the "bubble" from the Mountek nGroove to fit up in it, also there's a little "bridge" where the usb cord goes.

Hope you enjoy!

Printer:

Monoprice IIIP

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

10%

Make sure you drill the holes for the 5mm cylinders after printing, this isn't for a regular pegboard.

Visit my profile for more if you like this model ;)

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/daqwAwkxgW3

THINGIVIEW VIEWING took screen shot before i fixed part alignment..
part is correct and will print correctly. check it out on tinkercad.com

you will need to log into tinkercad in order to choose part to download,
reason for this is i left all changes and mods with originals together but not grouped.
this will allow you see what i did and to allow you to make any modifications you may need to make on your own.

modified holes for eccentric spacers from OpenBuilds.com $ 2.00 each
Don't forget mini wheel spacers shims 1mm thick
This modification will require 4 eccentric spacers per side 8 total for X axis

to make adjustments to mini wheel tension.
I also added place to insert screw for X endstop.
i combined 3 parts into 1
H-Bar LEFT
H-BAR RIGHT
X ENDSTOP ADJUSTING SCREW

instead of printing 3 parts that are different, now only need to print 2 parts the same.
2) H-BARS
no need to print X-axis end stop as it is now in the H-BAR
By doing this you also pick up 16mm of X axis space

they work for both sides and has end stop screw for x axis 3mm screw added
and the Y axis screw ( end stop )was increased to use a 5mm socket head screw

Printer:

GEEETECH ALUMINUM

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

no need for support. added built in support for screw hole.
its your option as to leave or remove the added supports for X axis end stop.
I removed and cleaned up.

description.text:
This is a lamp I am 3D printing for a 4H electric project. I am still uploading pieces but so far there is only the lamp shade or vase depending on what you will use it for. If you print make sure to add supports and to comment how it turned out so I may make improvements with the design. Also, the diameter is around three inches and it is about 7 inches tall.
Update 4/20/17:
I have now added a two part version so that smaller printers like mine can print it.
Update 4/21/17:
I have added nodes or whatever you call them to the two part lamp/vase in order to help assemble the two parts after printing. NOTE that this will NOT solely connect the two parts together that is why man made super glue.
Update 4/22/17:
This is a update for all those who are trying to make the 3D printed lamp. I have just added a screw wich will be placed in the middle of your base and what is basicaly a nut that will go on the screw and also be attached to the lamp shade (which is why it spins.)

Printer:

Prusa Mendel 13

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 is for great results but may print very slow.

Infill:

I would go around twenty percent or less to help suport the spiral.

3D Builder

I know, I know not the best way of making it and I do not recommend it for others because the lamp shade/vase in itself took me over three hours to make.
Uses Festo QSM-3 fittings, design allows for the new generation of these fittings that have oval shape ends

Printer Brand:

3D Systems

Printer:

Cube 3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.200mm

Infill:

15%

Finishing

After printing drill and tap for a 6-32 screw, these screws are coarser and wont strip the plastic as easily compared to the original 3mm screws. File the mating surface so the aluminum drive plate fits properly.

Assembly

Use 6-32 x .375 button screws to attach to the aluminum drive plate, and 6-32 x .500 to install into the cartridge.
Reverse engineered the stock drive plate, added the addition for the Festo connector using their CAD model.

author: Hyperlinks

title: Dual Mode Windup Car with windows.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This a slight remix of Dual Mode Windup Car by gzumwalt http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2054125

I loved the design but after printing the first one and showing to friends and family I noticed they didn't know which end was the front until I wound it up and showed them. I thought maybe if it had some head lights it would make it more clear I ended up also added a dual exhaust to it also.

I wanted the gears hidden so that it would look more like a Car model so I made some windows. I did all these changes with Tinkercad, it was a learning experience but I'm happy with the results but I do need to spend time with Fusion 360.

Only 4 parts are changed from the original design and they are:
Remix_Body_left_lights
Remix_Body_Right_lights
Remix_Body_top_cut-out
Remix_Car_Windows, The windows need to print on it's side with supports all the rest is support free (you will need to glue the windows to the top to make installation easier).

Not sure if it was an error but the design called for 16 size 222 (1 3/4 O.D., 1 1/2 I.D., 1/8" diameter) O-rings for the tires I could not install them on the rims they were too tight I ended up using size 223 (1-5/8" ID, 1-7/8" OD, 1/8" diameter) O-rings for the tires and they fit perfectly.

I printed everything at .02mm in PLA with 80% infill with 4 perimeters on Top, Bottom and Sides.

All of the originals parts are included here so you don't need to download anything else.

Install instructions are from the original and stay the same.
assemble Dual Mode Windup Car in the following order.

1) Position "Axle Spring.stl" into "Chassis Right.stl", then press "Spring.stl" and "Pawl.stl" onto "Axle Spring.stl".

2) Press one each of "Cross Member.stl" into "Chassis Right.stl" at the front and rear.

3) Press "Gear Floating Pinion Guide Right.stl" into "Chassis Right.stl".

4) Press "Gear Floating Pinion Guide Left.stl" into "Chassis Left.stl".

5) Press "Axle Gear Idler Large.stl" into "Chassis Right.stl". When fully installed, there should be 15.5mm between the inside surface of "Chassis Right.stl" and the shoulder on "Axle Gear Idler Large.stl".

6) Press "Axle Gear Idler Floating.stl" into "Gear Pinion Floating.stl". There should be 4mm of "Axle Gear Idler Floating.stl" extending from both ends of "Gear Pinion Floating.stl".

7) Press "Gear Axle Rear.stl" onto "Axle Rear.stl", aligning "Gear Axle Rear.stl" with the spline on "Axle Rear.stl".

8) Position the rear axle assembly in "Body Right.stl".

9) Position the floating idler assembly in "Body Right.stl.

10) Position "Gear Pawl.stl" onto the axle spring assembly.

11) Position "Gear Idler Large.stl" onto "Axle Gear Idler Large.stl".

12) Position "Spacer Axle Gear Idler Large.stl" onto "Axle Gear Idler Large.stl".

13) Position "Spacer Axle Spring.stl" onto "Axle Spring.stl".

14) Press "Body Left.stl" onto the body right assembly. When complete, the front and rear cross members must be flush with the outside surfaces of the body sides, and there should be 37mm distance between the inside surfaces of "Body Right.stl" and "Body Left.stl".

15) Install the o-rings on all wheels, then install one each of "Wheel Right.stl" and "Wheel Left.stl" onto the rear axle assembly.

16) Press "Axle Front.stl" into the remaining "Wheel Right.stl", then slide the assembly into position and press the remaining "Wheel Left.stl" onto the axle assembly.

17) Attach "Body Top.stl" onto the front and rear "Cross Member.stl".

Printer:

BigBox Pro

Yes

Resolution:

Print at:190 to 210 degrees C
Heated Bed temp 60 degrees C
I used Autodesk Fusion 360 to design this and Simplify3D to print this on my Vector 3D Printer. Once printed the 608RS bearings are simply pressed in.

We've all seen the video...

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HXuWQbF-n8s

Here is my first attempt at doing this. Took some time to set up, still not right (it has a pointed side) but I'ts a work in progress, and will be posted as such.

More or less a storage spot so I can share the file while I work on it.

UPDATE: I have created a full one now, with 12 frames. I also included a stand, so that you can attach it to the top of a standard size (6" Mag Light).

Of course, you want to print the movie reel with a transluscent materials. I would bet a metal flake would be the best. I would also suggest covering the bottom of the movie plate with black paint. I thought about it a little too late, so it will have to be tomorrow, but a separate thin layer printed in black should do the trick.

Press the MagLite into the hole from the bottom. It should press fit nicely. Next, take the movie reel, and place it on the cone shaped side. Give it a spin... Oh, turn on the flash light. :)

title: Dry Box Filament Guide - Prusa i3 MK2

description.text:
I needed a dry box. This holds the PTFE tube coming from the dry box securely on the Prusa MK2 frame.

This thing requires:

  • 1.5" spring ( http://www.harborfreight.com/200-piece-assorted-spring-set-67562.html )

I also used:

  • Screwless Filament Feeder - 1.75 - Dry Box ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1750875 )
  • Filament Dry Box 1.25" PVC Holders - ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1511834 )
  • 4mm O.D. 2mm I.D. PTFE tube
  • Air Tight Storage Tote - ( http://www.target.com/p/sterilite-174-54-qt-air-tight-storage-tote-transparent-with-blue-latch/-/A-15079778 )
  • Curved Filament Clip - ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1201137 ) ( just to secure the filament when not in use)

I used hot glue to secure the PTFE tube to the screwless filament feeders

The clip and fastener aren't quite perfect yet. I made it to be a tight fit on the Prusa MK2 frame, so if you have issues with elephant foot, you may need to trim it just a bit.

If you need any of these things printed, check out my 3Dhub: https://www.3dhubs.com/service/232732

15%

Version 1.0:

ToDo:

  • The clip pinches the sprint occasionally. A chamfer on the edges will probably fix it.
  • The fastener doesn't hold as well as I'd like. Probably extend the round internal bits a bit to hold better.
  • With very tall prints, the holder may not be high enough, and cause kinks. Needs testing.

title: Customizable modular marble track / Desk toy
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Make sure you print a few test pieces before one of the large plates; some people have reported that the default tolerance is too large for them and the track won't snap together. Change the tolerance variable in the customizer to .20 or .15 to make the fit on the pieces slightly tighter!

This is a set of modular marble track pieces that work well with 3/8" bearings (or other similar, small marbles.) By default, the track "unit" is 20x20x20mm; the open pieces of track are half-height, and the drops are double height. Print it out and use it (like I have) to avoid whatever important work you're supposed to be doing.

I've included:

  • the OpenSCAD file (which is parametric, and should work now),
  • two track set STL files (which are about 160x160, so should print on an i3)
  • individual STL files for each piece in the standard sets
  • an 8mm marble (which probably needs a raft/brim, and may not be heavy enough)

Updated on 21 Apr 2017: The .scad file now has better support for parametrization; if you use Thingiverse's customizer, you'll get a full set with one of each piece, which should make changing/remixing easier. I also squished the pieces together a little more in the track sets, which should reduce print time a little.

Printer:

CTC i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Prints well at 40mm/s and .3mm layer height on my cheap i3 clone. The pieces have (by default) .25mm of extra lateral room at the connectors; if your printer is nicer than mine, you might need to change this in the OpenSCAD file and re-generate the pieces / track sets.

description.text:
This is a totally functional, and almost-totally-printed click pen that I designed for an engineering interview. It's almost-totally-printed because you need to find a spring and ink cartridge elsewhere.

As you can imagine the tolerances on the parts need to be exact for the pen to function. Sharpen the edges of the teeth of the gear and plunger so that they are as fine as possible. Also lightly sand the different surfaces of the gear until it slides smoothly into the screwtop and plunger.

I've made four of these so far and they work great. I think assembly of the parts is pretty straight forward but in case not, note that the cylindrical extension on the gear is inserted into the hole in the plunger, and that assembly slides into the screwtop. The end of the ink cartridge should rest against the bottom of the gear.

Happy Printing

I used photogrammetry (camera on tripod taking pictures of object on turntable) to scan a wood carved hummingbird, stitch it together with Agisoft Photoscan. To print without support I split it in two with Netfabb Basic. Rotate halves to lay flat side on print platform. Feel free to recut for better printing. The angle on the bill will likely produce some stringing which for my print scrapes clean easily but an angle cut with beak and tail more vertical would reduce that issue. Alternatively you can cut off the beak and print separately.

description.text: Took the NES controller and made it into a bow tie

Have you ever gone to fill up your fuel cans and wound up losing the black plastic seal cap that fits above the nozzle when it is inverted in the tank and below the threaded cap? I own a small ranch, and constantly need to use my fuel cans. As such, I lose these little buggers all the time! Now, the cans should seal just fine as long as you leave the nozzle out in the "fill" position rather than stowed away in the "storage" position, but this is not always the case. I can't tell you how many times I went to grab a fuel can that I knew was full of gasoline, just to find out that despite the nozzle being in the fill position, the valve had failed and all of my fuel evaporated out of the can. So, to avoid any further aggravation I reverse engineered the cap, and designed it so that we can all simply print new seals!

  • Jim Kott

description.text:
This is an attachment for a z-probe that is mounted with 2 3mm screws which are 11mm apart.

It is for the printer by flsun which is known as "2017 Newest Large Printing Area 260x260x350mm Open Build Aluminium Frame 3D Printer kit printer 3d with Heated Bed" a.k.a. "New Design Aluminium Frame 3D Printer Kit Large Printing Area 260x260x350mm Open Build Size 3D Printer With Heated Bed" a.k.a. "High Accuracy 3D Printer Build Size 260x260x350 mm Large 3D Printer" ... and countless other variations.

This reduces the size of the usable buildspace by about 9mm to "only" 266mm. If you want to recover those, you can just drill a hole into this part where the y-belt attachment screw of the x-motor carriage hits it.

The probe offsets are X=50, Y=-10.

description.text:
Here you have some almost perfect scale models of the buildings that are situated ontop of the Universal Studios Hogwarts ride. The bedrock files are the foundations that all the buildings can rest on. Enjoy this enchanted incredibly detailed print of the Hogwarts castle. If you need any help on the assembly you can message me. There are still a few peices for the west wing to rest on. There will be a secret drawer that pops out from under the Great hall.

There has been a hidden drawer update and it has a secret locking mechanism if you reach behind the bridge to depress the lever. I would suggest before printing you add some coin slots up top so you can double it as a bank. A new update about the rear of the great hall. There will be a small pool that you can fill with water and dry ice. It has spouts that will direct the fog to run down and around the rocks surrounding the buildings on the west wing. Filling up the crevice between the two sides of the school.

The Full scale model when finished will have a video i upload of the entire Project running and operating smoothly. There will be some led's inside the spiral spire that move up and down representing the kids going to and from their dorms. And yes it will be an amazing nightlight effect because the windows on that building are open to the internals. Please share your print photos.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

No

.2mm

Infill:

.25

Notes:

I have a 0.4mm nozzle. Run everything at 235 C and keep the hot bed at 80 C. First layer prints at 0.15mm the rest of the model at 0.2mm layer height.

Design

Glancing back and forth from the Movie sets actual picture. Lining up sizes as if doing a painting.

description.text:
This is a replacement for damaged male ends for the expandable "pocket" hoses. I created this replacement to mimic the original that broke, but modified it so it could be printed without supports so you don't have to mess with cleaning threads out. I also made the decorative cap larger to allow use of a 3/8" PEX clamp to hold the hose to the end.

Make sure you print the main body at 100% infill. The high water pressure is sometimes enough to break through a normal print and will allow water to fill the voids eventually breaking through the outer shell. The cap is fine to print at what you see fit, it is simply decorative to hide the clamp.

For assembly, simply remove the damaged end by cutting the hose with scissors. Make sure to hold the hose tight when doing so, the inner hose can retract into the outer webbing and can be difficult to get back! Next, push a few cm of webbing back while holding the inner hose. Then slide your cap and clamp on far enough to give some working room. Slide the inner hose over the new end and follow by the outer webbing and clamp. Crimp the clamp making sure to get the outer webbing as well. If you don't, the inner hose will expand and pop - the webbing is what holds everything together. Finally, slide your cap up and cover your handiwork. Ta-da!

Printer:

MBot Grid II+

100%

description.text:
This thing will turn your whisky bottles into a classy headphone stand.
It is a redesign of my original here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1729644. This one includes two rings for added stability and better looks compared to the original.

Most Whiskeys bottles will fit withing the two tapered rings
The Upper ring around the cap tapers between 24-38mm.
The Lower ring around the neck tapers between 38-43mm

Lapphroaig
Lagavulin
Yamasaki

description.text:
DIY...In Space! Only a bit bigger! This is a PockeCube micro satellite frame for classroom or desktop use. The unit is a double sized 2p design (50mm x 100mm x 50mm). With this framework, you can build your own micro-satellite using a variety of ultra small logic systems such as Raspberry Pi Zero, Edison or Tinyduino.

The bundle includes a top plate, frame, base plate with mounting holes, and a mounting plate for a Raspberry Pi Zero. A full sized blank mounting plate and an extended (2/3 size) plate have been added as well for your own electronic designs. Additionally, the 2p PocketCube can also use the 1p plates (blank, Edison and Tinyduino) found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2255980.

Mounting the plates is done with M2 hardware. Two kits from Sparkfun (https://www.sparkfun.com/products/13187) should provide the basics. Hardware stores may have M2 components in stock or they may be able to order them for you. The Raspberry Pi Zero uses M2.5 mounting components instead of the M2.5. You will need screws, standoffs and nuts in this size as well if you plan to use a Pi Zero in your design.

Cleanup

Parts can be cleaned with a small file set and a hobby knife.

Origins

I created this in Autodesk Fusion 360 as a follow up project to my 1p PocketCube. This design is larger, allowing for different electronic sets to be incorporated into the satellite. It still works with the original plates and hardware used in the 1p version.

Cat Face Design

Search "wslab" for more designs.

title: M3D Micro PVC Large Filament Spool Holder

description.text: This is a large filament spool holder for the M3D Micro printer. It allows you to easily mount a full-size (1 kg) spool of filament above the frame of the printer. The design is modular in nature for easier printing on the M3D's tiny bed. It also requires several lengths of 1/2" Schedule 40 PVC pipe (actually 0.84" OD) which is incredibly cheap.

Printer:

M3D Micro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Printed with PLA on an M3D Micro with 4 outer walls. Infill setting doesn't matter much since there aren't any really thick areas. You'll need to print the following parts:

  • (4x) Clamp: 0.2 mm layers, self-supports
  • (2x) Clip: 0.2 mm layers, self-supports
  • (2x) Top: 0.35 mm layers, no supports
  • (4x) Base: 0.35 mm layers, no supports

The following hardware is needed for assembly:

  • (4×) M3 × 8 mm socket-cap screw
  • (4×) M3 hex nut
  • (1×) 2.5 mm allen wrench
  • Sandpaper (roughly 100 grit)
  • Two-part epoxy for plastic
  • About 3 feet of 1/2" Schedule 40 PVC pipe

Order of operations for installation:

  1. Sand each of the mating surfaces of the base, top, and clip parts.
  2. Epoxy together two pairs of base + top parts (top assemblies).
  3. Epoxy together two pairs of base + clip parts (bottom assemblies).
  4. Wait for the epoxy to fully cure (usually takes about an hour).
  5. Clip bottom assemblies onto opposite centers of the frame.
  6. Place a nut into each clamp part.
  7. Attach the clamps using screws (tightened hard).
  8. Cut two equal lengths of pipe for the uprights (roughly 6-8").
  9. Press-fit the two pipe pieces into the bottom assemblies.
  10. Press-fit the top assemblies onto the uprights and align them.
  11. Measure the distance for the crossbar, then cut a pipe piece to length.
  12. Place filament spool onto crossbar, then place crossbar onto uprights.

When inserting the nuts into their hex-shaped holes in the clamps, they may either be slightly loose or slightly tight. If the fit is loose then you'll have to hold them in place while threading the screws into them. If the fit is tight then you can apply some pressure to force them into place. The handle of a screwdriver works well for this.

The crossbar should sit loosely and turn freely on the uprights. The pieces of pipe do not need to be cut perfectly square. PVC pipe cutting tools will often result in cuts at a slight angle, and this is fine.

This design is based heavily on evandepol's parametric design. The original SketchUp file is available for download. The pipe pieces in the SketchUp file are for illustration only and are not sized to the proper lengths.

description.text:
Just another fidget spinner that I designed while messing around in 123D. It uses 5 608 bearings and can be printed without supports. As seen in the video, it can satisfy you fidgeting needs in multiple ways :)

WARNING: You do need relatively large hands for this. Or you may have to open your fingers wider in order to spin it. I had to scale it up by 101% when printing in ABS.

Should print in high infills (>30%). One file includes all pieces you need. Simply pres fit the caps in the bearings, press fit bearing into holder, and fit / super glue the holders into the main body.

Any suggestions or improvements would be appreciated as I'm still new to this!

title: "The Flying Box" - A 280mm Modular Quadcopter for 6" Props

description.text:
UPDATE 4/30/17: The arms actually fit onto the plate now! Make sure when you're printing that the X looking piece is flat side down (there's a .3mm lip that needs to be printed)

UPDATE 4/27/17: I added the files for the GPS mount, but I will be remaking it ASAP

UPDATE 4/25/17: Mount for GPS made (I didn't include the GPS pole since I'm still working on it), new, more ridged arms (still working on them!)

UPDATE 4/23/17: New FC plate to allow for better cable management and removal. The quad's height is now 47mm. (2-3mm added, I don't remember the exact number)

I designed this quadcopter for a senior capstone project. I created it with modular design in mind as well as autonomous flight. It is designed to carry a Raspberry Pi 3 Model B, a standard 36mm 250mm class flight controller (I am using the PixRacer V1 for autonomous flight).

The arms are modular, designed for standard 2204/2202 brushless motors with 16x19mm bolt pattern.

In the photos, I have printed it in eSun PLA Pro, but I plan to print in NylonX by Matterhackers.

The STLs are exact dimensions, so adjust your prints accordingly!

Updates will come regularly, as I make changes.

Bucket list:

  • Reinforce arms
  • Add landing gear
  • Change PDP to standard mounting pattern
  • Add mounting support for PX4Flow
  • Change the how the XT60 mounting
  • Move the RX holes
  • Adjust standoffs for new FC (PixRacer)
  • Add support for GPS mount
  • FPV
  • Create 'racing' middle stack (remove RPi3)

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

45%

Notes:

If you're slicing in Simplify3D, MAKE SURE DENSE SUPPORTS ARE OFF, especially for the arms!

Hardware
  • M3 x 45mm
  • M3 x 12mm
  • M3 hex nuts
  • M2.5 Screws
  • M2.5 Nuts

title: AM8 - Metal Frame for Anet A8

description.text:
Check out my new website for finding filament print settings: 3DPrintingDB.com

My goal is to make it easy to find a starting point when using a new filament. Please let me know what you think!

AM8 - A Metal Frame for the Anet A8

This project aims to build a sturdy aluminum frame for your Anet A8, while re-using as many components as possible to keep costs low. This frame can be built for roughly $55, plus the costs of plastic.

The BOM.pdf file contains all of the parts you need to buy and where to get them.
The Build_Guide.pdf has the build instructions.

This frame uses Misumi 2040 aluminum extrusions and aluminum corner brackets for primary frame connections, and printed plastic parts for alignment.

This project only aims to replace the acrylic frame of the Anet A8. The project was designed and built with a stock Anet A8 in mind, in an attempt to reach the widest audience. Many of the existing mods and upgrades should still be compatible with this new frame, although some upgrades may no longer be needed.

This project does not address any other issues with the Anet A8. Those issues should still be fixed on their own (Such as the mosfet mod).

Ideally, your Anet A8 is not your only printer, so that rebuilding it does not leave you without a working printer if something should go wrong with your build.

Build this at your own risk.

Optional Parts

The Anet Board Mount can be printed with or without an 80mm fan mount attached. I recommend mounting a fan to help keep the board cool. Any 80mm computer fan should work. If you are using a fan, please print or buy fan guards to prevent fingers or wires from going into the fan.

Additional Parts:

T-Slot Wire Cover
E3D V6 Mount

Update 10/21/17

Fixed broken Misumi links in BOM.
Added shorter bed screws to BOM to avoid interference with Y rod holders.

Update 5/13/17

Added E3D V6 Mount link

Update 5/6/17

Uploaded fixed STLs for the the following files:
Z_Motor_Mount_Right
Z_Motor_Mount_Left
Y_Motor_Mount
Z_Endstop
Anet_Board_Mount_No_Fan

All of the old files can be found in the old_stl.zip file

Update 4/28/17

Added Fusion 360 Design files

Update 4/22/17

Added missing link for M5 Square nut to BOM.

Anyone else have this problem? Everything else so far has fit perfectly, so I can't believe that my printer just did a bad job on those two parts. I'm not sure if I should try to carefully drill out the plastic, or modify the stl and reprint, which would add another day or two of printing to the job. Thanks.

comments.text: Mine fit tight, but I usually just tighten the screw into the plastic either using the threads on the screw, or putting a nut on the back and tightening it down. But if its too tight for that, drilling works fine too.

comments.text: Yeah, the screw heads were like 1-2mm larger than the opening. I just drilled it out slowly with a 3/8" bit and no problem. I do worry if it'll be stable but if it isn't I can always modify the stl and reprint in the future. Thanks.

comments.text: I would just recommend drilling it out. It is the quickest solution, and as long as you drill slowly (as to not melt the plastic) you should be fine. Use some washers to make it extra strong :)

comments.text: Question. Is cheaper /worth to buy separate parts to build this, or to buy and Anet a 8 to do it?
comments.author: ivomenezes

comments.text: You're better off buying loose parts, especially if the goal is to make a quality printer. The A8 is a collection of cheap parts - rods are crap, bearings are crap, H plate holding the heat bed is crap, wiring is crap, power supply is crap, the pushbutton user interface is horrible/slow compared to something with an actual knob you can turn, etc. You're paying for a bunch of parts you won't use (the frame) and you'll probably end up replacing a bunch of the other parts anyway.
comments.author: ivomenezes

comments.text: I have to disagree with your comments about the stock parts being junk. Maybe you got your A8 from a different vendor than me. The A8 is very inexpensive but if bought from a reputable dealer (I got mine from Gearbest) you wind up with a bunch of very good quality electronics. My A8 has been printing basically nonstop for a year or two without a hiccup. And I have abused the heck out of it.
comments.author: gmarsh23

comments.text: I stand by my statement.
comments.author: mitchilito

comments.text: The fact is, your are correct about every shortfall you mention about the stock A8. I have in fact addressed almost every one of these things: I direct soldered power to the heat bed (0 $), added a separate heat bed MOSFET ($3) and installed fans on the control board and cheapo power supply.   All this really has left me with a very reliable printer - and I say this after hours and hour of printing.

comments.text: is this frame really worht the upgrade and does it give better prints?
comments.author: hassehoff

comments.text: This may result in better prints depending on your setup, but the reason I'm upgrading is to cut out maintenance more than improving prints. If you don't have a frame like this, you will probably have to readjust and tighten the rods and nuts that hold your machine together every 2 months or so. I've found that the vibration of the machine loosen the connections over time. As far as prints go, if your axes aren't perfectly aligned, your printed objects will have skewed dimensions. So in that regard, this will improve print accuracy.
comments.author: hassehoff

comments.text: I printed mine in PLA originally, and it's held up pretty well, even in an enclosure. I'm in the process of desinging and upgrade and I'm printing those parts, and some replacements, in ABS. I'd recommend PETG or ABS if you can.
comments.author: Haniry

comments.text:
I used PETG and it worked great. Others had success with PLA too.
I try to avoid ABS as it warps and its not very healthy. PETG is most of the time a better choice.

comments.text: Ok, so I built this and it is nice and sturdy, but I cant figure out where to set the bed edges (When I print, the print is over to the left I would say about 30mm and towards the back by about 5-8mm). Can someone tell me where to either set the direct center of the bed (In relation to the print nozzle) or where to set the edges?
comments.author: sdernbach

comments.text: You will need to update your firmware and change the home position. To figure it out, home you X and Y axis. Then, using the LCD, move the head of the nozzle to the corner of the bed. Mark the X and Y position while the nozzle is at the corner. You need this to be 0,0 so take the ngative values of where you are at now and set that as your home position in firmware.
comments.author: sdernbach

comments.text: Has anyone had the Y belt tensioner on this mod actually fit each other part?  There was NO-way these parts would slide together after printing them.
comments.author: Sotm

comments.text: If you work the two parts together for 5 minutes they will loosen and work freely
comments.author: Sotm

comments.text: Yeah, I got them to fit perfectly by adjusting the horizontal offset from 0.00mm to -0.10mm when printing the Y block. This made the holes about 0.2mm wider without having to adjust the STL file itself. I printed the Y Belt Tensioner at 0.10mm layer heights and lowered the nozzle temperature for this object so the surface finish would be as perfect as possible. Picture attached.
comments.author: Sotm

comments.text:
On the BOM you list "corner brackets" but misumi calls them "reversal brackets". Corner brackets are something else that go inline with the extrusions instead of inside the joint.
Is there a reason you used single height brackets instead of double height brackets?
comments.author: evvo

comments.text: Thank you for the insight. The reason I used single height brackets was because I had them already. I made this frame almost entirely out of parts I already had leftover from an earlier project. So there may be some parts that are better suited, but I didn't want to publish instructions for parts I hadn't actually used.
comments.author: evvo

comments.text:
Sounds like a good reason to me!
I doubt the double height brackets would make much of a difference and it's fewer blind nuts to try to get screws into!!

comments.text: Anyone having issues with the z posts seeming to far back when set at 127mm per the manual?  Mine is exactly 127mm using one of the guides out there and when the extruder primes itself before a print, it misses the left front corner by about 10mm.  I am tempted to move the z axis forward 10mm to compensate but not sure why I am getting different results than others if the 127mm measurement works.  Comments/ thoughts would be appreciated.
comments.author: heatvent

comments.text: I changed in the configution.h of SkyNet the setting #define Y_MIN_POS from -10 to 0 and all was well again; #define Y_MIN_POS 0
comments.author: heatvent

comments.text: Thanks, I was just looking at changing that exact configuration.  I was planning to manually check the travel of the bed to make sure I don't lose 10mm in the process but I did notice that when XY are homed the position is the -33 and -10 per those settings.  Just want to make sure I can move the bed a full 220mm.  Otherwise, I may also try to do the rod_y end stop remix but it is a PITA to take everything apart again to swap that out.  I already did that once because the bed thumbscrews were hitting the y end stop so I reprinted with the rounded side facing out.  I will update once I have a chance to check this out. In some ways, good to see that I am not the only one having the issue.
comments.author: pipo1000

comments.text: So here is my assessment.  You can't move the Y endstop switch back because the bed will hit the Y stepper motor if you do.  You can only move it back maybe 1mm.
comments.author: heatvent

comments.text: OK, I think my plan of attack will be to reprint the y end stop with the switch back 1mm, just to get that little bit of extra travel for the y axis.  I currently have very close and maybe a hair less that 220mm.  Then I may move the Z extrusions back 3mm.  This should put the extruder at the edge of the bed.
comments.author: heatvent

comments.text: Indeed, with 360mm you could have made remixed Y axis end stops which only clamp 10mm (so same size block with only 10mm of clamp on it) of the rod instead of the full 20mm. This way it will still look nice (as designed) but you have more travel. However for me the last amount of travel on the Y axis is not really important at this point so  I will forget about this issue. I am thinking about building a Hypercube Evo and will use / dedicate the AM8 as my 'small' printer.
comments.author: heatvent

comments.text: I will probably make due as well. Although new extrusions are only about $7 so I am tempted to go with 350mm to keep the size still as compact as possible but allow for some additional travel.  I can always do this later if needed.

comments.text: can i convert my ctc prusa i3(geetech prusa i3 clone) to this frame?
comments.author: 7ohms2

comments.text:
Im looking to do the same, it should be possible, the only major difference is that the A8 is wider than the ctc i3.
If you install the top profile on top of ze Z beams in stead of in between them, you're able to adjust the width of the entire frame, without having to cut any of the beams(It will just look a little weird). According to some quick measurements it SHOULD fit. It is however possible that there will not be enough clearance for the build platform.
If it there isn't its possible to adjust the width of the X-carriage(the rods go pretty deep into the printed parts). if the guide rods still arent long enough you can order longer ones to replace the original ones.
Which you could also do in the first place and just stick with the design as it is.
comments.author: 7ohms2

comments.text: Hi - I've been building my AM8 today, however, when I got to the stage where I have to install the z axis extrusion.. the right leans over to the side. It only does it when I try to install the tee bracket. Would you be able to help? Thanks in advance
comments.author: harristhepoodle

comments.text: Sounds like the T-bracket exerts some force. While diagnosis is tricky my guess is that i) everything is ok, a little bit of stress/strain is normal and it will straighten out if you put the top extrusion on, or ii) the holes in the print are maybe a bit smaller / asymmetric and you can drill them to the correct size or iii) your printed T-bracket has not exactly the right dimensions, which would mean that you have to check also your other printed parts and potentially calibrate your printer and print once more.
comments.author: harristhepoodle

comments.text: I have ordered all parts and printed all things waiting for the delivery of the profiles. I have a question, I read about changing the acceleration and jerk settings to get better print quality in your PDF with the AM8 frane, however you do not mention your current 'winning' settings on Skynet of Marlin. Can you please share your settings / changes ?
comments.author: pipo1000

comments.text: I would also be interested in the 'official' settings by pheneeny. My experience is that the default settings of jerk = 20 is a bit much and I reduce it to 10 - 15 in Skynet/Marlin to reduce ringing, which is otherwise clearly visible on the X face of a calibration cube (ringing depends also on how hot and liquid your PLA is etc). My acceleration is 300 - 400, and I do not find print speeds between 30 and 60 mm/s to affect quality so much (jerk and acceleration are more (?) important), because Cura 2.6 prints the outer perimeter slower anyway.
comments.author: pipo1000

comments.text: Why is the position of the Z-column restricted to 127mm from the back?  It seems to me that absolutely anywhere along the y-axis would be find as long as both columns are at the same level.
comments.author: ccc_888

comments.text: The bed is limited in distance it can move by when the bearings hit the rod holders. At 127, the x axis is placed at a point where the hotend can cover the entire bed. Too far forward or backward would cause the hotend to not be able to reach parts of the bed.
comments.author: ccc_888

comments.text: pheneeny...see my post above, I had to move mine to 123mm to cover the full bed given the Y axis only covers 220mm of travel, I needed the Y axes to be at Y0 when homed.

comments.text: After a few prints I can confirm previous posts: printing at 100 mm/s gives me pretty bad ringing, printing at 50 mm/s is ok, but ringing is still a bit worse than printing at 30 mm/s with the old frame. One thing I notice is that the threaded rods for z movement vibrate a lot which may be a problem. Now I put a bearing holder without bearing but some some tape there to dampen any movement and will see whether things improve. Putting a bearing on the top of the z rods will also help against vibration, but may also introduce problems if the threaded ro is not perfectly straight.

comments.text:
Namedpipes, By not extending the side extrusions, you are not only losing print volume, you are also losing the ability to pause the machine.
You should not have troubles assembling this machine, Pheneeny did a good job at describing the assembly and when it comes to first layer adhesion, no matter how much you pray, it will not be right unless you have the proper distance from bed to nozzle, proper bed preparation as for example for pla, salt water spreaded evenly on the glass while at 60ºc with a damped tissue so when water evaporates while you are spreading, will leave a smooth fine coat of salt behind and believe me there is nothing better than this for pla, of course you can also use blue tape, hair spray, etc. For ABS Kapton tape on glass at 95ºc, PETG on Kapton tape at 70ºc. You must experiment with different nozzle temps, not all machines behave the same.

comments.text:
Fairplay4,
Sorry I created all this confusion,
All I did is replaced the 340mm extrusion listed in the BOM of this printer with 364mm extrusions when I built mine, that way I recovered the 24mm lost in length back to front and enabled ability to pause the machine.
If you assemble it with 340mm, the heat bed will collide with the front.
By using 364mm side extrusions, you bring it to the original anet a8 form and function dimensions.
And for the already printed parts, do not worry, you can still use the same parts.
I hope that Pheneeny analyze my change and approves for his machine.
Again I greatly thanks him for his contribution, His design allowed me to have a good superior working printer.

comments.text: I'm a little concerned about the 24mm lost to the thicker frame (20mm vs. 8mm) and think that making the Y-extrusions longer is the wrong way to go. The smooth rods will then only go 8mm into the holders rather than all the way through, doing little to improve stability. Especially because pressure and stability in the holders extend from the center. At least the screw should be moved towards the edge.
comments.author: Dansker61

comments.text:
Dansker61,
I'm just about to finish an AM8 with 364mm bed rods. I made new smooth rod holders for the front with internal stops to limit the movement of the rod and left the back smooth holders as the original AM8 to allow the rods to be pushed back in case you need to remove the bed. I left the screws holes and slot on all rod holders to allow compression of the rods but there is no need for the screw in the front ones. The smooth rods do not add stability to the machine, as long as the holders do not allow movement up or down or sideways, it should be fine, the rods can even move back and forth and it wouldn't matter since the movement of the bed is dependent of the belt. Stability is achieved with the extrusions. I'm in the process of building another machine that will replace the carriage rods with 2020 extrusion as well.
I will publish all my new additions later today.
comments.author: Dansker61

comments.text:
Totalguy
check https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2283772, there you will find what you need.
The z run is actually reduced by 24mm and if you ever pause your machine during printing, the printing bed will collide with the front of the frame. If you measure the Rod clearance between the two original acrylic plates, it will be aprox. 365mm. With this frame, the clearance is 341mm. I will replace the two 340mm side rails with 364mm to avoid collision. I'm always making prototypes that require embedded nuts and I have to pause the printing process very often. If you are not planning to never pause printing, then use the 340mm rails.
Is a beautiful machine, all my problems went away and I've been printing at 80mm/s instead of a max of 50 in the past.
Check my carriage level indicator (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2409837), it will save you a lot of time to bring the carriage to proper heights.
comments.author: totalguy

comments.text: I like it. But while you are at it, have you considered how to make the printer say 300x300x340 or so? What would that entail in the way of software changes, different settings, etc? When I take this project on, I want to use larger diameter ACME screws, larger rods, etc so why not make it larger. What do you think?
comments.author: DeveK

comments.text: I would be hesitant to create an i3 style printer that big. The problem with the i3 is the moving bed gets exponentially heavier as the size increases. A bed that big will need to be thicker to maintain flatness and be very heavy, making it difficult to print with any decent speed without artifacts. If you want to build a printer that large, you should go with a CoreXY design that only moves the bed in the Z direction. I have a D-Bot that is 300x300, and it works very well.
comments.author: DeveK

comments.text: That's not necessarily a problem. The important thing is the smooth rods are parralel with each other. With the lead screws on flex coupler and unconstrained on the top, they are allowed to wobble, with the nut being the pivot point. This should prevent any bends in the lead screw from affecting the print, although severe bends will still cause problems.

comments.text: is there anything for the threaded z axis screw for the wwoble thing
comments.author: kostasbmw

comments.text: The design should be able to tolerate a little lead screw wobble. The flex coupler on the bottom and the un-constrained top of the lead screw means it should move with the nut as the pivot point, allowing the rails to hold the axis steady. If you constrain the ends of the lead screw, any bends in it will be forces onto what it's carrying.

comments.text: I did have both Igus and standard (but decent) LM8UUs available, but just used the LM8UUs. In theory Igus should work and definitively reduce the noise level. Completed my AM8 Conversion and is very happy with the result. Better Precision prints and much lower noise/vibration. Thank you for the design! I decided to use ATX PSU (safer) and mount Mosfet Board Close to the PSU. In case someone is interested you can find detalis here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2369496
Please note that my frame does have some extra alu profiles. I also designed a new Z-endstop to be able to adjust it from the left side. (I removed my y-endstop published earlier and used the one designed by thaug). Some cable management remains, but I have done the importent stuff like fixing all cables from the hot end to the extruder Carriage. Please remember that parts of this thing is hot, it vibrates and components may fall off...

comments.text: Love this build, but wanted to flag one issue that has cropped up for me.  I printed a set of bed-leveling wheels to use M3 nuts instead of the wingnuts under the Y-carriage, and noticed that they won't work because the wheels (even small ones) clip the Y-axis rod holders.  The front right clamp could feasibly be flipped around, but the rear clamp that also holds the Y-axis endstop can't be reversed.
comments.author: mjvaders

comments.text: There is a solution to this problem, flip the rod holders around so the screw is on the inside giving more room for the bed-leveling wheels, print a fourth one for the right rear and use this www.thingiverse.com/thing:2357071 to mount the endstop.  I did the same thing to mine and all is well.  I also just published a remix of the Y axis endstop holder for a RAMPS endstop if you are using them.  With this frame this thing prints as well as many expensive commercial 3D printers.

How much plastic did you use for all the pieces?
Is PLA rigid enough?

comments.text: I used about a half a kg for the actual final prints. PLA is definitely rigid enough, the biggest concern with PLA is parts close to the bed or hotend deforming due to the heat. I did all of my original parts in PLA because I have much better success rate with it and I was doing a lot of iterations. I've since replaced parts near heat with PETG.
comments.author: AVZ

comments.text: I used about half a kilogram for the parts I printed, I did not print the display case because I am using RAMPS v1.4 with the lcd 12864 smart controller.  I used PLA and it seems to be rigid enough since the majority of the frame strength comes from the 2040 extrusions and the corner brackets which are cast aluminum.

comments.text:
First off, amazing design. If you stray way from the BOM file of parts/suppliers be aware that 2040 profiles differ slightly from company to company, as well hardware can differ also. I state this only because I got all my parts in, only to find out that my drop in nuts do not "drop" into the channel nor do they slide in from the side. I like the idea behind the drop in option because you don't have to disassemble the printer to make changes.
Once again not criticism of the great frame. Just a note to builder.

comments.text:
I'm almost done with designing the electronics box. All i need to do is the lid and means of attaching it. Want it to be almost screwless if possible. Maybe only 1 or 2 locking screws instead of the 6 standard all cases are using.
IT has space for the board and 2 of the much used mosfet boards. And the idea is that you place a M3 bolt through the case and place the nut on the inside of the case against your component. The benefit from this is, that the head of the bolt will sit flush with the back of the case and does not stick out of the box.
Here is a screenshot of the box so far, and one complete will upload it as a remix of course.

comments.text:
Thinking about it more, there are two issues. The
nuts need to be narrow enough so that they can slip into the t-slot channel, but also wide enough so that they can't spin feeling in the slot. The square nuts will slide into the slot, but when you tighten the screws, the corners of the nuts will push against the sides of the t-slot, stopping them from spinning. That allows you to tighten it down.
comments.author: JivRey

That's a major mod. nice looking too!

I do believe that having the Anet gave me a ton of knowledge about 3Dprinting, since I (and I believe any Anet printer owner) does need to do a lot of troubleshooting in order to get things going.
Gratz on your mod!
comments.author: robb_nl

comments.text: Thanks! The Hypercube is a nice CoreXY design that allows you to re-use a lot of the components from your existing printer. I originally thought of going CoreXY with this build, but decided that I wanted to stick with direct drive extruder, so I probably wouldn't be able to take advantage of the increased speed of a CoreXY, so I stuck with the standard Prusa style design.
comments.author: robb_nl

comments.text: This looks great!  I've been looking for something more sturdy than the acrylic.  I plan to do this in the near future!

comments.text: This is great i purchased the rubbers from amazon and the crews from the links you posted but the misumi website is really confusing its giving me a ton of options besides the length is there anything else i need to modify? Example:
comments.author: shaunalvarez

comments.text: If you follow the links from the BOM for the Misumi extrusions, there are really only two fields you need to worry about. The Anodized option at the top will determine the color of the extrusions. The extrusions in the pictures are "Clear Anodized". You can choose "Black Anodized" if you want black extrusions, but they cost a little more.
comments.author: shaunalvarez

comments.text: Thanks ill check that out later defenetlly  and post back. What about a e3d volcano setup how would i mount my extruder motor since currently the mount is on the top right of the frame and i see you made no additional brackets for different setups any ideas?
comments.author: pheneeny

comments.text: Hmm, good question. I planned to stick with direct drive on mine, so I didn't put much thought into how a bowden setup might work. There are a number of extruders that are designed to connect to the 2020 and 2040 extrusions. You may be able to remove one of the rear plastic corner brackets at the top of the vertical extrusions and mount it there. I don't think you will lose much structural integrity without that bracket as long as you have the aluminum bracket there as well.
comments.author: shaunalvarez

comments.text: I am using this to mount the extruder on my Bowden setup. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2279743 2020 Extruder Motor Mount on the top right side. I tapped the outside hole on the right upright, mounted it with two m5 screws and 1 square nut in the slot on the top cross piece. I also put a washer under each bolt head to spread the load on the printed part. Nice solid simple mount.
comments.author: pheneeny

comments.text: gmarsh23:  I guess I need to order some more parts, I like the tweaks you came up with.  I will place a second order with Misumi for 1 x HFS5-2020-273,  and 6 x HBLFSDW5 so I can do all four corners also.  I am going to see if I can get the printed parts for joining the Z towers to the top piece made from aluminum.  I know some people with CNC machines at home that might be able to make them for me.
comments.author: gmarsh23

comments.text: I've got 6 x HTPSSL5 joining the Z bars to the top, in place of the plastic pieces, which would accomplish the same thing as using aluminum plates. I use 2 on the back, and 1 on the front below the Z rod holder. Another change I'd make is changing the -273 bar to -271 to make up for variation in the cut length, it doesn't have to butt against the Y bars since it's held against the Y bars by the NF5's.
comments.author: PapaJohn88

comments.text: I purchased 6 x HBLFSDW5, used one on each corner in addition to the two you recommended.  I also put in the 273mm cross piece at the bottom to have place to fasten the fixed end of my under bed cable chain.  I will be posting photos of my make today after I finish the wiring.

It works really well, maybe even better on the AM8 frame since there is additional room under the bed. Check my make later today for photos of my completed AM8. There are some of the underside after I installed everything for the Y axis including the cable chain.
comments.author: gmarsh23

comments.text: @gmarsh23, Did you have any problems with the HTPSSL5 not being thick enough and therefore not securing properly to the extrusion? I think you either need to purchase m5x8 screws or print a spacer to put between the screw and the SSL5. Thoughts?
comments.author: gmarsh23

comments.text: I'd suggest using a metal washer, not a printed spacer, as you can put a lot more torque on it and get better clamping between the SSL5 and the frame. Or use M5 x 8mm screws as you're suggesting.
comments.author: jokeman3000

comments.text: gmarsh23, where do i have to put the HFS5-2020-273, at the bottom from left to the right?

comments.text: Yes, across the bottom from left to right, joining the Y extrusions together opposite the Z extrusions. Two NF5s on each side, one front and one back, connect it to the Y bars.

title: 3D Printer Scalable XY Dual Motor on Y Belt Drive

description.text:
Attention please:

This project is only a drawing, I haven't realized the real thing yet, so, before printing or before milling any single part, check well the Sketchup file and check any possible mistake.

3D Printer XY Axis, Belt Drive, scalable.
Version with 2 Motors on Y Axis
Please check .stl file because I am not sure about the exporting into .stl

-Linear Rails: Hiwin HGR 15 or equivalent measurements
-Frame: aluminium Profile 30x30 (to stay cheap).
-Pulleys: HTD 3M 16 Teeth - Belt 9mm width

-Z axis lifting Bed to be improved for the desired size.

The X plate and the 2 support blocks should be in aluminium with precise surface or other metal.

The other parts could be printed.

Before printing any part check the holes size in order to reduce the diameter to the desireday screw to thread.

I am not an expert in Thingiverse, to be sure about files to download you can also look in 3D Warehouse.

title: Tevo Black Widow Drag Chain Mounts for Outer Z Wheel Mod

description.text:
This is an extended horizontal drag chain mount for use on the Tevo Black Widow with the outer z-wheel modification. There are two versions included. One with a channel to run the wiring and the other without to run the wiring in an external loom between the two drag chains. There are three sets zip-tie slots to secure the wiring in the channel version and I have also added a zip tie hole on the corner of the external loom version as well.

This bracket is intended to replace the corresponding drag chain bracket in this horizontal drag chain mod for printers with modified outer z-axis wheels. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2073061

title: Dillon 550 Casefeeder 9mm/380ACP caliber conversion
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I had issues with the 9mm/.38 Super caliber conversion for my casefeeder. Often times it would double feed or jam due to the additional height necessary for .38 Super. This is only high enough for 9mm. After desiging/printing/installing this, case misfeed, double feeds and lay down cases stopped.

Looking at clearance on the case pusher shoe, this is as long as I can make it. But it should also help out with 380 as it does with 9mm. 38 Super is quite a bit longer than either 380 or 9mm.

Printer:

CTC 3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

35%

description.text: for nerf destiny

I leave here the necessary files to continue with this fish board game for children. (Solidworks 2015 & STLs).

For anyone who wants to continue. The fish are functional and tested (even their cavity in the water).

To complete the game it is necessary to add the motorization.
The basic idea was a DC motor with printed 3D pinion + internal gear on the base wall of the game - (movable part). All this is blown by a base in which the water rotates and has the wedges to raise the fish.

I can not find time to finish it for now

description.text:
An easy-to-print maraca design made especially for little hands.

Put in beans, split peas, or salt - each will make a different sound!

Includes a hole at the top to attach some string, like a shoelace.

http://a360.co/2pJZ1sG

Notes:

Used a 5mm brim; since it's a tall and skinny model, this can help, especially for around the first solid layer after infill, where the finish can get rough. With 2 perimeters and 4 top / 3 bottom layers, came out plenty strong.
It's a revolved profile sketch in Fusion 360, with a hole plus an embossed R on the bottom. Pretty easy.

title: Looney Pyramids / Icehouse pieces
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are standard-sized Looney Pyramids, a.k.a. Icehouse Pieces. You can play a large number of games with these: https://www.icehousegames.org/wiki/index.php?title=What_Can_I_Play%3F
An even larger catalog of games becomes possible when combined with a Piecepack set.

These pieces come with holes in the side indicating the size of the piece (small, medium, or large). The edges and points are rounded for reduced skin-puncturing incidents.

I've also designed a storage tray for the pyramids, and a "cradle" so you can store rows of pyramids updside-down between rows of upside-up pyramids, in order to minimize the amount of storage space needed. The storage tray can hold five stashes (a stash is five trios, and a trio is a single piece in each of the three sizes).

comments.text: This looks interesting. I'm not familiar with "Icehouse", is this a type of Open Source game rule set that can be used with these peices? Thanks so much for sharing this. I'm sure this would have lots more LIKES! if people understood a little more :)
comments.author: MakeTheFuture

comments.text: These pyramids are what's known as a game system; like a deck of cards, there are many games you can play using these pieces.
comments.author: MakeTheFuture

title: Helical Horror, a twisted torture test

description.text:
3D-printer torture tests being all the rage, I decided to test overhanging features (35° angle from the horizontal) in combination with a tightly turning (35 mm diameter) torus on top.
A simple instruction to how I made it is included.

I think my Zortrax M200 did well, but there is a ripple effect visible on the underside that I don't know the cause of, and the bridging of the curve was (of course) impossible... ;)

Edit: the first STL file was incorrectly positioned, uploaded a new file with the Z axis pointing UP... Both files are otherwise identical!

Edit2: Added two closeups of the wavy undersides, one from the Helical Horror, and another from a lattice cube with the same dimensions, but with straight lines instead of curves! The waves are less pronounced in the lattice cube, but they are still there. X-Y resolution issues? Resonance?

Edit3: Added a final photo, printed the object at 0.09mm layer height, and resized to 200%. The wavy pattern is almost invisible, and the only flaw is the beginnings of a slight drip beneath the overhanging parts, but that is easily removed with some sandpaper.

Printer Brand:

Zortrax

Printer:

Zortrax M200

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,19 mm, coarsest possible

Infill:

Maximum

I started out with a thin plate to mount the helixes (sp?) on, and added the first using the "Create > Coil..." command.

I made two more copies of the coil using the Move command Three coils turning the opposite direction, created with the Mirror command Added a torus... Nudged the pieces together with Move, and made a single body with

description.text: I wanted to make a protective case for my 'Ledger HW.1' bitcoin hardware wallet that was quick and easy to use. Since nobody else seems to have made a design for it, I figured I'd share mine.

Printer:

Vulcanus V1

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

30

Notes:

For the main body, you want the flat side to be facing the bed. For the 'slide', you want the largest flat side facing the bed, (the 2 rails should not be touching the bed, no supports needed for this part). For the 'pusher', the two obtrusions should be facing the bed (supports needed, see below).

You will only really need to use supports for the 'pusher'. Make sure none of the supports intersect with the stuff on the bottom of the 'pusher' that will interface with the Ledger hardware wallet.

Assembly Step 1

Cut/sand the nub off the end of the Ledger that is leftover from snapping it out of the plastic sheet it came in (it's on the end that is opposite of the USB part).

Assembly Step 2

Put the pin on the pusher through the hole on the Ledger. The 'pusher'/Ledger combo should look like in the picture.

If you want, you can superglue the two together. It's not really necessary though.

Assembly Step 3

Slide the 'pusher'/Ledger into the rails, and all the way to the back of the case.

Assembly Step 4

Apply two small drops of superglue to the rails of the 'slide', then slide it into the rails of the case until it is flush with the outside of the case. You may need to push the tab of the pusher down in order to slide the 'slide' to where it needs to go.

Allow the superglue to dry, then slide the pusher back and forth a few times to break it in.
