title: Glow Knife
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted a glowing bladed knife for a sci-fi cosplay costume. So I designed this one. I used the handle from Herman_Lundgren's Bayonet (CS:GO Knife), because I felt it had the right sort of military sci-fi look.

It is designed to fit the common 20.5cm by 0.5cm (8"x1/4") glow sticks, which I get in packs of 50 for a few dollars. They are the ones used to make necklaces and bracelets. They just slip in the hole in the base, and press into the socket at the tip. I find they are a close enough fit that they don't move about, but if needed you could just wrap a bit of sticky tape around the end of the glowstick, and it should hold it in place quite securely.

The plastic doesn't quite transmit as much light as I would like, but if you put the glowstick in boiling water before breaking it the light is very bright.

This is a prop, It doesn't have an edge, and will likely break if you tried to stab someone.

Printer:

Wombot XL

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.05mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed this upright with a 30 line brim in PLA at 205 degree nozzle and 55 degree bed. I printed it at 100% scale.

comments.text: this is so awesome. try printing in carbon fiber... :o
comments.author: PHILdesign

comments.text: I should also point out; This knife is NOT for stabbing or cutting with.  I deliberately designed the blade to snap off for safety reasons.  I also made it practically impossible to sharpen.  Even if you did print it out of carbon fibre, you won't be able to put an edge on it and it will break very easily.  While you can hurt someone with it, a good sharp pencil would be more dangerous.

title: Reinforced Easy Print Front Intake Guards for Blue Robotics T100 and T200 thrusters

description.text:
This is an update of my printable Blue Robotics Thruster intake guards for use with the T100 and T200 thrusters.

The origional guard offers slightly less drag, but is weaker and more difficult to print. These guards are strong, can be printed without support and are fully open source (additional source files available, just let me know what you need)

These 4 files were were commissioned and sponsored by the fine folks at Seafloor Systems, Incorporated http://seafloorsystems.com/ and were concieved of as an open source update to the origional designs, to benifit the ROV and boating community. Feel free to take a look at their website, they have some neat stuff there!

85% or better

Notes:

These print sitting flat on the bed. The flat layer, no edge one is probably going to be the simplest to print, but offers the least protection. File 2d is closest to my origional intake guard design.

Instructions:

To use, remove the 2 M3 metric bolts that hold the nose cone to the thruster, and slip this in place, then reattach using the stock screws. If you print this in ABS it should be fine down to at least 300 feet or so, posibly deeper if you coat it with epoxy paint.

description.text:
What is even better than having a Raspberry Pi as a printing server for your SmartAlu by SmartFriendz? Having it installed IN the printer itsefl! :)
For this, you need a well designed support, right?… Well, here it is!
It's quite simple, actually. You'll just need 3 M3x12 bolts and nuts to install your RPI (2B or 3B) on the support, then 2 M4x12 bolts and hammer nuts to install the whole thing on the printer's aluminium structure.
Plug everything, start your server (I use OctoPi, which is pretty cool), and you're good to go. :)

Thanks to the Hotend Family and the unique IDEX system of the BCN3D Sigma you will be able to push the limits of 3D printing by combining different hotend sizes. Use a 0,3mm hotend to print the outlines and a 1,0mm hotend to print the infills and get an excellent finish in up to 3x less time! Or print a big, intricate model with 0,8mm hotend and use an 0,4mm hotend to print detailed PVA supports. You have thousands of combinations! It may sound complicated, but you can download flawlessly the right printing profile, no matter the hotend configuration you have installed in your Sigma, thanks to the Sigma ProGen (https://www.bcn3dtechnologies.com/en/sigma-progen/).

Finally, in case you plan to print massive objects with an 0,8mm or 1,0mm nozzle, you may need to upgrade your Purge Bucket.

For the right one, just use the mirror option on your slicing software ;)!

description.text:
these are a selection of the current frame add-ons I use on my stock CF ZMR250 frame

they include:-
Arm end/Motor protectors
PDB & FC vibe&conductivity isolation mount
cam mount (interior AIO version, Exterior AIO version,CCD/CMOS angled version)
LIPO alarm/ VTX mount
LIPO plug mount
Sandwich plate spacers (front/rear/sides)
Sandwich plate LED strip mount spacer (front/rear)

Ive used all of these designs at various points in time and all have proven reliable and robust enough to survive my sometimes less than gentle flying style.

notes:

The motor guards are suited for upto 28mm sized motors

The FC and PDB mount is designed to accommodate a full sized 50x50 PDB and multiple types of FC (a KK2 type can me screwed directly down onto the mount while other smaller types are mounted using foam 3m tape which also adds to vibe dampening)

The LIPO plug mount can be attached to any of the ZMR standoffs so can be located wherever the builder chooses

The AIO cam used is the Eachine TX03 but its dimensions are the same as the TX02 and TX01 AIO's also, these dimensions are also similar to other brands of AIO cams but please check before use

Boite pour RaspberryPi en mode domotique, le pilotage est assuré par la plate forme Cayenne. Un shield est utilisé mais n'est utile que pour la lecture des numéro de broche...

La boite est constituée de 4 éléments à imprimer.

deux sondes 18B20 (tous deux connecté sur l'entrée GPIO 4 du bus 1 wire)
trois Relais monté sur glissière dans la boite afin de faciliter leurs câblages.
quatre Leds dans le couvercle peut importe la couleur
une sonde hygrométrique en mode logique (logement prévue pour le montage par vis dans la boite et ouverture dans le fronton pour le câble de la sonde)
un capteur PIR (présence infrarouge) trappe dans le couvercle
...
évolution possible : détection d'ouverture de porte, ajout de nouvelle sonde de température, bouton poussoir..

////////////// Les stl ont subis une petite mise à jour ///////////////

espacetechno.info
------------------------------------------------+Box for RaspberryPi in home automation mode, piloting is ensured by the platform Cayenne. A shield is used but is only useful for reading the spindle number ...

The box is made up of 4 elements to be printed.

Two 18B20 probes (both connected to the GPIO 4 input of the 1 wire bus)
Three relays mounted on a slide in the box to facilitate their wiring.
Four LEDs in the lid no matter the color
A hygrometric probe in logic mode (housing intended for mounting by screw in the box and opening in the front for the cable probe)
A PIR sensor hatch in the lid
...
Evolution possible: detection of door opening, addition of new temperature sensor, push button ..

description.text:
A simple BLTouch calibration tool.
It is designed to be 8,3mm high as this is the distance specified in the spec sheet.
Printing
The spec gives 8,3mm +/- 0,2mm : should be printed accordingly. Layer height must be chosen carefully.
I have a 1,8° Z stepper driving a 8mm/revolution threaded rod with 200 steps for 1mm.
Good layer heights for this config are (sweet spots at full steps) :
0,08, 0,16 and 0,32 giving -0,02mm difference with the desired height.
If you don't know this for your printer, use 0,1mm.
Infill isn't important.
Of course printing too high and adjusting using a file is also an option ;)

Procedure
1 : set these screws loose and move BLTouch up as far as possible
2 : Move bed up and align calibration tool unter the BLTouch and flat on the bed.
3 : move bed further up until nozzle touches the bed
4 : lower BLTouch until it sits on the calibration tool and lock the position with the 2 screws

description.text:
This is a customizable case design, created in OpenSCAD, for holding different sizes/amounts of DIP-style ICs. Might also work with some SMD style chips, just change the straddle_height to be lower and gutter sizes to be wider.

If you need lots of storage for lots of little chips, I recommend DIP IC Organizer by bbales. (In the Remix section)

Printer:

DaVinci Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I suggest not using supports for the overhang regions, but if your printer can't do it reliably, use them. They can make it difficult to slide on the lid unless you don't mind filing/acetoning the rough supported areas.

Here are the settings for some common chip types.
Wide Dip:
chip_length: 53
gutter: 2.3
straddle_width: 7.5

Short Wide Dip:
chip_length: 38
gutter: 2.3
straddle_width: 7.5

Standard DIP
chip_length: (number of pins/2) * 2.5
// ^ may need to add a mm or two for extra space. Use calipers or something to make sure
// but this uuusuuallly works
gutter: 2
straddle_width: 5

Updates

2017/04/23

Added a column feature. In the future might make it more flexible, but it will attempt to make it as 4-sided as it can by rounding up the number of chip it needs. i.e. if you want six chips across two columns, it will make two columns of three.

title: Mockup of the Dual Nimble aka Nimble C/C

description.text:
This is the Mock-up for the Dual Nimble. It is only intended to give provide you with a clear idea of the overall size of the Dual Nimble. It is NOT a working model.

Edit: Hey I see I did not add the Step and Iges files of the mockup. I have now.

The Dual Nimble is perfect for the E3D Chimera/Cyclops hot end. It simply bolts straight on top of the main heat sink block. It is very flexible in mounting positions, it can be mounted with the fan facing forward or facing backwards.

Included is a drawing of the mounting hole positions. Slightly over the top as the holes are identical to the holes on top of the Chimera/Cyclops.

The Nimble Extruder

The Nimble Extruder

With an installed weight of less than 27 grams on your carriage/effector the Zesty Nimble is smallest and lightest extruder you can buy, it has ample torque and can be mounted in multiple orientations.

The Nimble is available from Zesty Technology.

title: ProgRock enclosure
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an enclosure for a programmable crystal replacement available from QRP labs (https://www.qrp-labs.com/progrock.html). The kit consists of a minimalist controller for a Si5351A clock generator chip and can produce up to three squarewave outputs between e few kHz and approx 300 MHz. It can be GPS disciplined for accuracy better than 1 ppm and up to 8x3 frequencies can be programmed via a serial interface.

The enclosure consists of a bottom- and a top part.
The bottom part holds the PCB and includes a hole through which the RX/TX-signals of the serial interface are accessible. For this and the other connections I use Dupont line connectors, which are glued with two part epoxy adhesive to the enclosure walls next to the holes.
The top part has holes for the power supply (5,5/2,5 mm DC socket), the SMA-connector for the CLK0 output, a header with all the frequency outputs, the connector for the GPS (optional, if not used connect 1pps to ground) and finally a 3-way DIP switch for selecting the frequency bank. This DIP switch is soldered to a small piece of Veroboard and afterwards the Veroboard glued in place.

Additionally one will need 4 self-tapping screws 3x6 mm to mount the PCB and 4 self-tapping screws 3x9 mm to tighten the bottom- and top-parts together.

Printer:

BQ Hephestos

No

No

0,2 mm

20%

Printed with PLA on a heated bed (60°C).
